Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Developing Alternate Aquafeeds by Using Sustainable Methods of Bio-remediation of Seafood Residuals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to enhance global food security. Aquaculture is the fastest growing agroindustry while the world fisheries catch has leveled out. Consequently, half of all seafood consumed today is farmed. Unfortunately, at least 30% of fish feed is derived from forage fish, the anchovy and sardine-types at the base of the food chain. With demand for forage fish growing while wild populations remain level at best, the price of fish meal and oil (FM&0) climbs by 15% yearly. Clearly, dependence on FM&O is unsustainable. For fish farmers to thrive without abusing the oceanic ecosystem, substitutes are essential. One solution is to use vegetable-based ingredients such as wheat and soy, but these lack vital omega-3 fatty acids. Another is to turn to the insect world, especially by culturing ecofriendly black soldier fly larvae (BSFL). The larvae are fed seafood residuals mixed with marine kelp and/or microalgae so that the natural omega-3 passes through. The larvae are dried and separated into FM&O-like meal and oil. The overarching question is: can this be accomplished competitively? Apparently it is possible, but a 2-year pilot plant is required to prove the practicality.

The proposed project will not only demonstrate that very large volumes of BSFL can be cultured using omega-3 loaded wastes and algae, but that substitute fish feeds that are palatable, stimulate growth and confer health are feasible. This is best achieved by simultaneously conducting feeding trials with a variety of species, including isolated bottom dwellers such as black sea bass and, alternatively, schooling pelagic creatures such as California yellowtail. Observing degrees of palatability is straight forward. But as with any cuisine there are numerous ways to enhance the offering: live, dried or pelletized and, if the latter, unit size, moisture content and even some surface additive that confers a natural taste ? perhaps crab-like for black sea bass and squid-like for California yellowtail. Such refinements grant significant economic margins by virtue of better survival rates, shorter time in the tanks and less costly ingredients. At this local level, both the farmer and the consumer benefit while globally these gains can favorably impact food security, especially with marine species that only require saltwater, with recirculating system that discharge little or no waste and, of course, with substitute foodstuff derived from waste bio-remediated by flies.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

The goal of NSF SBIR Phase II number 1534772 was to produce an alternative source of fish meal through the production of Black Soldier Fly Larvae (BSFL) feeding primarily on post-process seafood residuals. The resulting larvae would be processed for extraction of protein and Omega-3 oil. The production system developed by Acadia Harvest, Inc. (AHI) was designed as an “open”, wet process that would allow a small crew using a forklift to grow large quantities of larvae.  The larvae were fed seafood residuals initially and then with lower cost and more conveniently available bakery, tofu and other food residuals. The process produced a residual “waste” consisting of saw dust and wood chips (used as bulking agents), frass (larval feces), and a liquid leachate, all of which could have proven to be additional marketable products as agriculture amendments and biostimulants. Both pulverized BSFL and leachate were tested as top-coatings on commercially available feeds with hopes of making feeds more palatable, especially for freshwater fish under culture; although encouraging, the results of these test were not conclusive. The designed system proved successful in rearing large numbers of larvae. However, while the “open” process was successful in growing BSFL, several problems developed. Production in a cold climate required the operation to be enclosed in a heated building to maintain the requisite growing temperature. Once fully enclosed, ammonia generated by the growing larvae caused ammonia levels in the production area to increase to dangerous levels despite the installation of a heat recovery ventilation system. In warmer weather, ventilation was managed by opening windows, doors, and an overhead door; however, having large openings led to contamination of the nursery and grow-out with other insects despite screening of the openings.  The “open”, wet process is technically feasible for growing BSFL, but the cost of operation from this system economically makes it unfeasible as a fish meal replacement, particularly in competition with large, heavily-financed enterprises that were developed over the course of the AHI project, growing BSFL at much larger scale. Nevertheless, we believe that bulk production using large containers manipulated by heavy equipment is worth further investigation. We also believe that the liquid leachate produced by the wet system also deserves further investigation. Furthermore, we believe top-coating feeds with larval products and leachate is worthy of further investigation. 

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2018
Modified by: Chris Heinig

The process produced a residual "waste" consisting of saw dust and wood chips (used as bulking agents), frass (larval feces), and a liquid leachate, all of which could have proven to be additional marketable products as agriculture amendments and biostimulants. Both pulverized BSFL and leachate were tested as top-coatings on commercially available feeds with hopes of making feeds more palatable, especially for freshwater fish under culture; although encouraging, the results of these test were not conclusive. The designed system proved successful in rearing large numbers of larvae. However, while the "open" process was successful in growing BSFL, several problems developed. Production in a cold climate required the operation to be enclosed in a heated building to maintain the requisite growing temperature.
